article_title: Texas ranked last nationally for health care access and affordability
article_text:
Texas ranked last nationally for health care access and affordability Report: State’s overall performance up slightly

Photo: Associated Press File Photo Tyler Day Nursery teacher Jacqueline Dade-Mack holds her son,...

Texas’ overall health care performance improved slightly, but the Lone Star State was ranked dead last among all states nationwide for health access and affordability and second worst for prevention and treatment in a nonprofit health research group’s assessment released late Tuesday.

article_metadata.description: Texas’ overall health care performance improved slightly, but the Lone Star State was ranked dead last among all states nationwide for health access and affordability and second worst for prevention and treatment in a nonprofit health research group’s assessment released late Tuesday.  Research has shown that even in areas and states with limited resources, strong leadership from providers, policymakers and businesses, among others, can lead to improvement that will assure all of us have the opportunity to benefit from a strong and thriving health care system.  The scorecard ranked all states and the D.C. area based on 42 indicators measuring health care access, quality of care, avoidable hospital use, costs, public health and equity.  All states dropped below 20 percent in this category for the first time in 2014, likely because of greater insurance coverage and improvements in the economy, said David Radley, a senior scientist tracking health system improvements for the Commonwealth Fund.  Around 17 percent of Texans under 65 years old were found to have high out-of-pocket medical expenses, meaning 10 percent or more of their annual incomes were used to pay such costs or, for low-income residents, 5 percent or more of their earnings.  “In our case studies of high- and low-performing states, we find that leadership and policy, combined with local health care system action, does make a difference — even in areas with fewer resources,” McCarthy said.
article_metadata.author.name: By Peggy O'Hare, Staff Writer
